item.title: Pakistan Hangs Guard for Assassination of Outspoken Secular Politician
item.description: Malik Mumtaz Hussain Qadri fatally shot Salmaan Taseer, the governor of Punjab Province and a staunch opponent of the country’s blasphemy law.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Malik Mumtaz Hussain Qadri in 2011 after his arrest in the fatal shooting of Salman Taseer, a secular politician, in Islamabad, Pakistan.

item.title: Day 2 of Syrian Partial Truce Is Marred by Violence
item.description: A number of airstrikes and artillery attacks, reported by the warring sides, demonstrated the challenges of even a limited deal.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Syrian rebel fighters on Sunday in a rebel-controlled area on the outskirts of Damascus, the capital.

item.title: Toronto Journal: In Toronto, a Neighborhood in Despair Transforms Into a Model of Inclusion
item.description: An ambitious plan for the 69-acre Regent Park neighborhood is disrupting entrenched notions of class, race and religion, at a time when concerns over income inequality and immigration are growing.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hassan, whose parents are immigrants from Japan and Egypt, practiced with his swim team at the Regent Park Aquatic Center in Toronto.

item.title: Twin Suicide Bombings Kill at Least 20 as Shabab Violence Intensifies in Somalia
item.description: The Islamist militant group the Shabab said it carried out consecutive suicide bombings in the city of Baidoa that killed at least 20 people.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: A Chilean Ex-Soldier Guiltily Recalls His Unit’s Atrocities
item.description: Guillermo Padilla says he was part of a commando unit in 1973 that tortured and executed suspected opponents of General Augusto Pinochet.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.media:credit: Victor Ruiz Caballero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Guillermo Padilla served in a commando unit that spent months combing towns and remote outposts in southern Chile in 1973, searching for suspected opponents of the military dictatorship of General Augusto Pinochet.

item.title: With Humility, Starbucks to Enter Italian Market
item.description: Howard D. Schultz, head of the coffee chain, credits Italy’s distinct coffee culture for inspiring him to create the Starbucks of today.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Two Bombings Kill Dozens at a Baghdad Market
item.description: The Islamic State claimed responsibility on Sunday for two attacks at a market in the Sadr City district that killed at least 42 people.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY
item.media:description: The site of two bombings on Sunday in the Sadr City district of Baghdad. Dozens were killed.

item.title: Netanyahu Welcomes Cease-Fire in Syria, but Adds a Warning
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that Israel would continue to defend its own interests and would block any Iranian-backed attacks from Syrian territory.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in the Golan Heights this month. Israel has repeatedly stated that it does not take sides in the Syrian civil war, but over the last few years numerous airstrikes in Syria have been attributed to it.

item.title: Facing the Taliban and His Past, an Afghan Leader Aims for a Different Ending
item.description: Abdul Jabar Qahraman, who surrendered Lashkar Gah to rebels two decades ago, has returned as President Ashraf Ghani’s representative and tried to negotiate, rather than fight, with today’s insurgents.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Afghan soldiers in Helmand Province, where the Taliban control or contest at least 10 of 14 districts.

item.title: Rescue Workers and Miners Are Killed in Russia Accident
item.description: Six rescue workers were killed on Sunday in a failed attempt to reach 26 stranded miners at a coal mine in Russia. The trapped miners were also declared dead.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Russian Emergency Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescue workers on Sunday at a coal mine in Vorkuta, Russia, where methane explosions triggered underground fires, killing miners and some of those trying to save them.

item.title: In Iran Elections, Conflicting Forecasts Emerge Along Rival Lines
item.description: After many reformist candidates won in large cities where results had been announced, state media suggested a nationwide triumph for hard-liners in areas waiting for results.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Downtown Tehran on Sunday. In the capital, where results are official, the urban middle classed voted in large numbers for the combined list of reformers and moderates who support President Hassan Rouhani.

item.title: Twin Bombing Attacks in Baghdad Market Kill at Least 59
item.description: Militants attacked an outdoor market on Sunday in eastern Baghdad, killing at least 59 people and wounding nearly 100, officials said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China Deletes Microblog of Critic of President Xi Jinping
item.description: An official statement said the property tycoon Ren Zhiqiang had exerted a “vile” influence by spreading illegal information on the Sina Weibo platform.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Ren Zhiqiang during an appearance in September at Wuhan University in Hubei Province.

item.title: The Libya Gamble: A New Libya, With ‘Very Little Time Left’
item.description: The fall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi seemed to vindicate Hillary Clinton. Then militias refused to disarm, neighbors fanned a civil war, and the Islamic State found refuge.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE and JO BECKER
item.media:description: Destruction in Benghazi, Libya, last July after fighting between pro-government forces and an alliance of former anti-Qaddafi rebels linked to the extremist group Ansar al-Sharia.

item.title: The Libya Gamble: Hillary Clinton, ‘Smart Power’ and a Dictator’s Fall
item.description: The president was wary. The secretary of state was persuasive. But the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi left Libya a failed state and a terrorist haven.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER and SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton at the end of a one-day trip to Tripoli, Libya, on Oct. 18, 2011, after the fall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Media reports referred to it as a “victory lap.”

item.title: Bolivian Town Drifts From President Evo Morales, Despite Promises Kept to Left
item.description: Residents of Cobija, which has prospered under ​Mr. Morales, expect his left-wing policies to continue even though he was denied the chance to seek another term.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Evo Morales School in Cobija, a $650,000 project that was never completed because a developer vanished after receiving money from the government.

item.title: Yemeni Civilians Killed by Airstrike on Market, Witnesses Say
item.description: At least 30 people were reported dead after a bombing by the Arab coalition that could add to calls for an international arms embargo on Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Ex-Official Calls for Malaysian Prime Minister to Step Down
item.description: A Malaysian official who has been removed from a top party job said he had seen proof that Prime Minister Najib Razak committed a crime related to the country’s sovereign wealth fund.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.media:description: Malaysia’s former deputy prime minister, Muhyiddin Yassin, with prime minister, Najib Razak, in Kuala Lumpur last year.

item.title: Italy Growers Wary of Olive Oil Fraud as New Law Is Weighed
item.description: Olive oil producers in the nation are troubled by draft legislation that would tinker with penalties for passing off counterfeit olive oil and its origin.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicola Fazzi, the director of the Colli Etruschi cooperative, among a member’s olive trees in Blera, Italy. He called a draft decree an attempt to “decriminalize adulterated oil.”

item.title: Monarch Butterfly Migration Rebounds, Easing Some Fears
item.description: Monarch butterflies, which fly each year to Mexico from Canada and the United States, covered about 10 acres this winter, an area more than three times as large as last year.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:description: Monarch butterflies last year in Mexico. They fly more than 2,500 miles south each year from Canada and the United States.
